speaker: Clown
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: Clown
text_entry: SCENE I. Verona. An open place.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE and PROTEUS

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Were't not affection chains thy tender days

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I rather would entreat thy company

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To see the wonders of the world abroad,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Than, living dully sluggardized at home,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Even as I would when I to love begin.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wish me partaker in thy happiness

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: If ever danger do environ thee,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And on a love-book pray for my success?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That's on some shallow story of deep love:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That's a deep story of a deeper love:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For he was more than over shoes in love.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Coy looks with heart-sore sighs; one fading moment's mirth

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If lost, why then a grievous labour won;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: However, but a folly bought with wit,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Or else a wit by folly vanquished.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Love is your master, for he masters you:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And he that is so yoked by a fool,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The eating canker dwells, so eating love

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And writers say, as the most forward bud

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Even so by love the young and tender wit

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Losing his verdure even in the prime

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And all the fair effects of future hopes.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That art a votary to fond desire?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Once more adieu! my father at the road

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Sweet Proteus, no; now let us take our leave.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To Milan let me hear from thee by letters

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Of thy success in love, and what news else

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Betideth here in absence of thy friend;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And likewise will visit thee with mine.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: As much to you at home! and so, farewell.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: He after honour hunts, I after love:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: He leaves his friends to dignify them more,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: War with good counsel, set the world at nought;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter SPEED

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: An if the shepherd be a while away.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: and I a sheep?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I do.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: This proves me still a sheep.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: True; and thy master a shepherd.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: shepherd; but I seek my master, and my master seeks

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: not me: therefore I am no sheep.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: wages followest thy master; thy master for wages

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my letter to Julia?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Ay sir: I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: lost mutton, nothing for my labour.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: carrying your letter.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You mistake; I mean the pound,--a pinfold.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: your lover.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But what said she?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [First nodding]  Ay.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Nod--Ay--why, that's noddy.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: You mistook, sir; I say, she did nod: and you ask

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: me if she did nod; and I say, 'Ay.'

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And that set together is noddy.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Now you have taken the pains to set it together,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: take it for your pains.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No, no; you shall have it for bearing the letter.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why sir, how do you bear with me?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly; having nothing

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: but the word 'noddy' for my pains.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Open your purse, that the money and the matter may

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: be both at once delivered.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her; no,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: and being so hard to me that brought your mind, I

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: mind. Give her no token but stones; for she's as

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: hard as steel.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What said she? nothing?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.' To

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: me; in requital whereof, henceforth carry your

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: letters yourself: and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which cannot perish having thee aboard,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Being destined to a drier death on shore.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit SPEED

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I must go send some better messenger:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Receiving them from such a worthless post.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. Garden of JULIA's house.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter JULlA and LUCETTA

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That every day with parle encounter me,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: According to my shallow simple skill.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine;

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: But, were I you, he never should be mine.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: How now! what means this passion at his name?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: That I, unworthy body as I am,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Your reason?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I have no other, but a woman's reason;

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I think him so because I think him so.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: His little speaking shows his love but small.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: They do not love that do not show their love.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: O, they love least that let men know their love.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I would I knew his mind.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Peruse this paper, madam.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: That the contents will show.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Say, say, who gave it thee?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: He would have given it you; but I, being in the way,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Did in your name receive it: pardon the

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: fault I pray.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To whisper and conspire against my youth?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And you an officer fit for the place.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Or else return no more into my sight.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Will ye be gone?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: That you may ruminate.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: It were a shame to call her back again

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And would not force the letter to my view!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And presently all humbled kiss the rod!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: When willingly I would have had her here!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: How angerly I taught my brow to frown,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: My penance is to call Lucetta back

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And ask remission for my folly past.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What ho! Lucetta!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Re-enter LUCETTA

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: What would your ladyship?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Is't near dinner-time?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I would it were,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: That you might kill your stomach on your meat

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: And not upon your maid.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What is't that you took up so gingerly?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Nothing.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Why didst thou stoop, then?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: To take a paper up that I let fall.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And is that paper nothing?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Nothing concerning me.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Unless it have a false interpeter.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Give me a note: your ladyship can set.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As little by such toys as may be possible.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And why not you?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I cannot reach so high.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Let's see your song. How now, minion!

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out:

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: You do not?

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: No, madam; it is too sharp.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: You, minion, are too saucy.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Nay, now you are too flat

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Here is a coil with protestation!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Tears the letter

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Go get you gone, and let the papers lie:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: You would be fingering them, to anger me.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: She makes it strange; but she would be best pleased

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: To be so anger'd with another letter.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I'll kiss each several paper for amends.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.' Unkind Julia!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As in revenge of thy ingratitude,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I throw thy name against the bruising stones,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Till I have found each letter in the letter,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And throw it thence into the raging sea!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: 'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To the sweet Julia:' that I'll tear away.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And yet I will not, sith so prettily

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: He couples it to his complaining names.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Thus will I fold them one on another:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Re-enter LUCETTA

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Madam,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Dinner is ready, and your father stays.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Well, let us go.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If you respect them, best to take them up.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down:

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I see you have a month's mind to them.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see;

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I see things too, although you judge I wink.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Come, come; will't please you go?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. ANTONIO's house.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter ANTONIO and PANTHINO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Why, what of him?

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: He wonder'd that your lordship

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: While other men, of slender reputation,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Some to the wars, to try their fortune there;

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Some to discover islands far away;

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Some to the studious universities.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: For any or for all these exercises,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: He said that Proteus your son was meet,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: And did request me to importune you

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: To let him spend his time no more at home,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Which would be great impeachment to his age,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: In having known no travel in his youth.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Whereon this month I have been hammering.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I have consider'd well his loss of time

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And how he cannot be a perfect man,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Not being tried and tutor'd in the world:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Experience is by industry achieved

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And perfected by the swift course of time.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: I think your lordship is not ignorant

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: How his companion, youthful Valentine,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Attends the emperor in his royal court.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I know it well.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: There shall he practise tilts and tournaments,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: And be in eye of every exercise

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: The execution of it shall make known.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Even with the speediest expedition

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: With other gentlemen of good esteem,

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Are journeying to salute the emperor

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: And to commend their service to his will.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Good company; with them shall Proteus go:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And, in good time! now will we break with him.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, that our fathers would applaud our loves,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To seal our happiness with their consents!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O heavenly Julia!

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: How now! what letter are you reading there?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Of commendations sent from Valentine,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Lend me the letter; let me see what news.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: There is no news, my lord, but that he writes

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How happily he lives, how well beloved

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And daily graced by the emperor;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And how stand you affected to his wish?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As one relying on your lordship's will

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And not depending on his friendly wish.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: My will is something sorted with his wish.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: For what I will, I will, and there an end.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: With Valentinus in the emperor's court:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: What maintenance he from his friends receives,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To-morrow be in readiness to go:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Please you, deliberate a day or two.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To hasten on his expedition.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exeunt ANTONIO and PANTHINO

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Lest he should take exceptions to my love;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And with the vantage of mine own excuse

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Hath he excepted most against my love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, how this spring of love resembleth

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The uncertain glory of an April day,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And by and by a cloud takes all away!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Re-enter PANTHINO

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you:

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: He is in haste; therefore, I pray you to go.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE and SPEED

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Sir, your glove.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Not mine; my gloves are on.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ha! let me see: ay, give it me, it's mine:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How now, sirrah?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: She is not within hearing, sir.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Your worship, sir; or else I mistook.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Well, you'll still be too forward.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Go to, sir: tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: She that your worship loves?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, how know you that I am in love?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: like a malecontent; to relish a love-song, like a

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: robin-redbreast; to walk alone, like one that had

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: the pestilence; to sigh, like a school-boy that had

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: lost his A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: buried her grandam; to fast, like one that takes

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: walked, to walk like one of the lions; when you

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: looked sadly, it was for want of money: and now you

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: on you, I can hardly think you my master.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Are all these things perceived in me?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: They are all perceived without ye.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Without me? they cannot.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Without you? nay, that's certain, for, without you

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: were so simple, none else would: but you are so

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: without these follies, that these follies are within

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: you and shine through you like the water in an

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: physician to comment on your malady.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Hast thou observed that? even she, I mean.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, sir, I know her not.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: knowest her not?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Sir, I know that well enough.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What dost thou know?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favour infinite.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: That's because the one is painted and the other out

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: of all count.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How painted? and how out of count?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that no

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: man counts of her beauty.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: You never saw her since she was deformed.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How long hath she been deformed?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Ever since you loved her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I have loved her ever since I saw her; and still I

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: see her beautiful.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: If you love her, you cannot see her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes;

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: ungartered!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What should I see then?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Your own present folly and her passing deformity:

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: for he, being in love, could not see to garter his

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Belike, boy, then, you are in love; for last

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: True, sir; I was in love with my bed: I thank you,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: you swinged me for my love, which makes me the

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: bolder to chide you for yours.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: one she loves.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And have you?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I have.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Are they not lamely writ?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: here she comes.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [Aside]  O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Now will he interpret to her.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Enter SILVIA

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [Aside]  O, give ye good even! here's a million of manners.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [Aside]  He should give her interest and she gives it him.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Unto the secret nameless friend of yours;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Which I was much unwilling to proceed in

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But for my duty to your ladyship.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I thank you gentle servant: 'tis very clerkly done.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For being ignorant to whom it goes

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I writ at random, very doubtfully.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No, madam; so it stead you, I will write

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Please you command, a thousand times as much; And yet--

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: A pretty period! Well, I guess the sequel;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And yet I will not name it; and yet I care not;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And yet take this again; and yet I thank you,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [Aside]  And yet you will; and yet another 'yet.'

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What means your ladyship? do you not like it?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Yes, yes; the lines are very quaintly writ;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: But since unwillingly, take them again.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Nay, take them.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Madam, they are for you.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Ay, ay: you writ them, sir, at my request;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: But I will none of them; they are for you;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I would have had them writ more movingly.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If it please me, madam, what then?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Why, if it please you, take it for your labour:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And so, good morrow, servant.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: My master sues to her, and she hath

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: taught her suitor,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: He being her pupil, to become her tutor.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: O excellent device! was there ever heard a better,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: That my master, being scribe, to himself should write

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: the letter?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How now, sir? what are you reasoning with yourself?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that have the reason.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To do what?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: To be a spokesman for Madam Silvia.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To whom?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: To yourself: why, she wooes you by a figure.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What figure?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: By a letter, I should say.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, she hath not writ to me?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: What need she, when she hath made you write to

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No, believe me.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceive

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: her earnest?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: She gave me none, except an angry word.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, she hath given you a letter.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I would it were no worse.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply;

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I have dined.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Ay, but hearken, sir; though the chameleon Love can

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: victuals, and would fain have meat. O, be not like

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: your mistress; be moved, be moved.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: SCENE II. Verona. JULIA'S house.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS and JULIA

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Have patience, gentle Julia.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I must, where is no remedy.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When possibly I can, I will return.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If you turn not, you will return the sooner.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Giving a ring

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why then, we'll make exchange; here, take you this.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Here is my hand for my true constancy;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And when that hour o'erslips me in the day

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The next ensuing hour some foul mischance

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Torment me for my love's forgetfulness!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My father stays my coming; answer not;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The tide is now: nay, not thy tide of tears;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That tide will stay me longer than I should.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Julia, farewell!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit JULIA

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What, gone without a word?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, so true love should do: it cannot speak;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter PANTHINO

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go; I come, I come.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. A street.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter LAUNCE, leading a dog

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping;

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: all the kind of the Launces have this very fault. I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: have received my proportion, like the prodigious

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: court. I think Crab, my dog, be the sourest-natured

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wringing her hands, and all our house in a great

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: one tear: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: has no more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wept to have seen our parting; why, my grandam,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: shoe is my father: no, this left shoe is my father:

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: no, no, this left shoe is my mother: nay, that

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: cannot be so neither: yes, it is so, it is so, it

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: it, is my mother, and this my father; a vengeance

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: on't! there 'tis: now, sit, this staff is my

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: am the dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: dog--Oh! the dog is me, and I am myself; ay, so,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: so. Now come I to my father; Father, your blessing:

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping:

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: now should I kiss my father; well, he weeps on. Now

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: come I to my mother: O, that she could speak now

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why, there

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes. Now

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter PANTHINO

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Launce, away, away, aboard! thy master is shipped

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: and thou art to post after with oars. What's the

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: matter? why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! You'll

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: What's the unkindest tide?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: thy voyage, lose thy master, and, in losing thy

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: service,--Why dost thou stop my mouth?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Where should I lose my tongue?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: In thy tale.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: In thy tail!

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Sir, call me what thou darest.

speaker: PANTHINO
text_entry: Wilt thou go?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Well, I will go.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: SCENE IV. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Servant!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Mistress?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, boy, it's for love.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Not of you.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Of my mistress, then.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Twere good you knocked him.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Servant, you are sad.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Seem you that you are not?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Haply I do.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: So do counterfeits.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So do you.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: What seem I that I am not?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Wise.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: What instance of the contrary?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Your folly.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: And how quote you my folly?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I quote it in your jerkin.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: My jerkin is a doublet.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: How?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Give him leave, madam; he is a kind of chameleon.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: in your air.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: You have said, sir.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: 'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Who is that, servant?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave the fire. Sir

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: make your wit bankrupt.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer of words,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: and, I think, no other treasure to give your

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: followers, for it appears by their bare liveries,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: that they live by your bare words.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: No more, gentlemen, no more:--here comes my father.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Enter DUKE

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What say you to a letter from your friends

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Of much good news?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My lord, I will be thankful.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To any happy messenger from thence.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To be of worth and worthy estimation

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And not without desert so well reputed.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Hath he not a son?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, my good lord; a son that well deserves

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The honour and regard of such a father.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: You know him well?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I know him as myself; for from our infancy

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: We have conversed and spent our hours together:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And though myself have been an idle truant,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Omitting the sweet benefit of time

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Made use and fair advantage of his days;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: His years but young, but his experience old;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And, in a word, for far behind his worth

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Comes all the praises that I now bestow,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: He is complete in feature and in mind

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: He is as worthy for an empress' love

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: With commendation from great potentates;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And here he means to spend his time awhile:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Welcome him then according to his worth.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For Valentine, I need not cite him to it:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I will send him hither to you presently.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Had come along with me, but that his mistress

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Upon some other pawn for fealty.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blind

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: How could he see his way to seek out you?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Upon a homely object Love can wink.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Exit THURIO

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Not so, sweet  lady: but too mean a servant

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Leave off discourse of disability:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My duty will I boast of; nothing else.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And duty never yet did want his meed:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: That you are welcome?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That you are worthless.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Re-enter THURIO

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I'll leave you to confer of home affairs;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: When you have done, we look to hear from you.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exeunt SILVIA and THURIO

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And how do yours?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I left them all in health.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How does your lady? and how thrives your love?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My tales of love were wont to weary you;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I know you joy not in a love discourse.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I have done penance for contemning Love,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For in revenge of my contempt of love,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And hath so humbled me, as, I confess,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: There is no woe to his correction,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Nor to his service no such joy on earth.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Now no discourse, except it be of love;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Upon the very naked name of love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Was this the idol that you worship so?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No; but she is an earthly paragon.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Call her divine.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I will not flatter her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And I must minister the like to you.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Yet let her be a principality,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Except my mistress.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Sweet, except not any;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Except thou wilt except against my love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And I will help thee to prefer her too:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: She shall be dignified with this high honour--

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And, of so great a favour growing proud,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And make rough winter everlastingly.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothing

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: She is alone.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Then let her alone.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And I as rich in having such a jewel

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The water nectar and the rocks pure gold.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My foolish rival, that her father likes

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Only for his possessions are so huge,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is gone with her along, and I must after,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But she loves you?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: marriage-hour,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With all the cunning manner of our flight,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Determined of; how I must climb her window,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The ladder made of cords, and all the means

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go on before; I shall inquire you forth:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I must unto the road, to disembark

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Some necessaries that I needs must use,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And then I'll presently attend you.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Will you make haste?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I will.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit VALENTINE

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Even as one heat another heat expels,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Or as one nail by strength drives out another,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: So the remembrance of my former love

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Is by a newer object quite forgotten.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Is it mine, or Valentine's praise,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Her true perfection, or my false transgression,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That makes me reasonless to reason thus?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She is fair; and so is Julia that I love--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which, like a waxen image, 'gainst a fire,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Bears no impression of the thing it was.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And that I love him not as I was wont.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, but I love his lady too too much,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And that's the reason I love him so little.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How shall I dote on her with more advice,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That thus without advice begin to love her!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: 'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And that hath dazzled my reason's light;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But when I look on her perfections,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: There is no reason but I shall be blind.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: If I can cheque my erring love, I will;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: SCENE V. The same. A street.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter SPEED and LAUNCE severally

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: say 'Welcome!'

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: did thy master part with Madam Julia?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: fairly in jest.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: But shall she marry him?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: No.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: How then? shall he marry her?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: No, neither.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: What, are they broken?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: stands well with her.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: staff understands me.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: What thou sayest?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: and my staff understands me.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: It stands under thee, indeed.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: But tell me true, will't be a match?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! if he say no,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: The conclusion is then that it will.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: thou, that my master is become a notable lover?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I never knew him otherwise.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Than how?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse;

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: name of a Christian.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: At thy service.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: SCENE VI. The same. The DUKE'S palace.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And even that power which gave me first my oath

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Provokes me to this threefold perjury;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: At first I did adore a twinkling star,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But now I worship a celestial sun.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And he wants wit that wants resolved will

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But there I leave to love where I should love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: If I lose them, thus find I by their loss

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I to myself am dearer than a friend,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For love is still most precious in itself;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And Silvia--witness Heaven, that made her fair!--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I will forget that Julia is alive,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Remembering that my love to her is dead;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I cannot now prove constant to myself,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Without some treachery used to Valentine.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: This night he meaneth with a corded ladder

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Myself in counsel, his competitor.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Now presently I'll give her father notice

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Of their disguising and pretended flight;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: SCENE VII. Verona. JULIA'S house.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter JULIA and LUCETTA

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And even in kind love I do conjure thee,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Who art the table wherein all my thoughts

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Are visibly character'd and engraved,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To lesson me and tell me some good mean

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: How, with my honour, I may undertake

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: A journey to my loving Proteus.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And when the flight is made to one so dear,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Pity the dearth that I have pined in,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: By longing for that food so long a time.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: But qualify the fire's extreme rage,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: The current that with gentle murmur glides,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But when his fair course is not hindered,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: He makes sweet music with the enamell'ed stones,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: He overtaketh in his pilgrimage,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And so by many winding nooks he strays

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: With willing sport to the wild ocean.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Then let me go and hinder not my course

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I'll be as patient as a gentle stream

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And make a pastime of each weary step,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Till the last step have brought me to my love;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: But in what habit will you go along?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Not like a woman; for I would prevent

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: The loose encounters of lascivious men:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As may beseem some well-reputed page.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To be fantastic may become a youth

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Of greater time than I shall show to be.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: What fashion, madam shall I make your breeches?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What compass will you wear your farthingale?'

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Out, out, Lucetta! that would be ill-favour'd.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: For undertaking so unstaid a journey?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I fear me, it will make me scandalized.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Nay, that I will not.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Then never dream on infamy, but go.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: If Proteus like your journey when you come,

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: No matter who's displeased when you are gone:

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And instances of infinite of love

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: All these are servants to deceitful men.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Base men, that use them to so base effect!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

speaker: LUCETTA
text_entry: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To bear a hard opinion of his truth:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Only deserve my love by loving him;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And presently go with me to my chamber,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To take a note of what I stand in need of,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To furnish me upon my longing journey.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: My goods, my lands, my reputation;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Come, answer not, but to it presently!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I am impatient of my tarriance.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter DUKE, THURIO, and PROTEUS

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: We have some secrets to confer about.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exit THURIO

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My gracious lord, that which I would discover

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The law of friendship bids me to conceal;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But when I call to mind your gracious favours

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Done to me, undeserving as I am,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My duty pricks me on to utter that

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which else no worldly good should draw from me.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: This night intends to steal away your daughter:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Myself am one made privy to the plot.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I know you have determined to bestow her

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And should she thus be stol'n away from you,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: It would be much vexation to your age.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To cross my friend in his intended drift

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Than, by concealing it, heap on your head

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A pack of sorrows which would press you down,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Which to requite, command me while I live.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This love of theirs myself have often seen,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And oftentimes have purposed to forbid

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Valentine her company and my court:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But fearing lest my jealous aim might err

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And so unworthily disgrace the man,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The key whereof myself have ever kept;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How he her chamber-window will ascend

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And with a corded ladder fetch her down;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For which the youthful lover now is gone

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And this way comes he with it presently;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But, good my Lord, do it so cunningly

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That my discovery be not aimed at;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For love of you, not hate unto my friend,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon mine honour, he shall never know

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That I had any light from thee of this.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Adieu, my Lord; Sir Valentine is coming.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Please it your grace, there is a messenger

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That stays to bear my letters to my friends,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And I am going to deliver them.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Be they of much import?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The tenor of them doth but signify

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My health and happy being at your court.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I am to break with thee of some affairs

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I know it well, my Lord; and, sure, the match

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Were rich and honourable; besides, the gentleman

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Neither regarding that she is my child

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Nor fearing me as if I were her father;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, where I thought the remnant of mine age

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I now am full resolved to take a wife

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And turn her out to who will take her in:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For me and my possessions she esteems not.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: There is a lady in Verona here

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And nought esteems my aged eloquence:

speaker: DUKE
