text_entry: Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For long agone I have forgot to court;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Besides, the fashion of the time is changed--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How and which way I may bestow myself

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Dumb jewels often in their silent kind

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Send her another; never give her o'er;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For scorn at first makes after-love the more.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But rather to beget more love in you:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For 'get you gone,' she doth not mean 'away!'

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But she I mean is promised by her friends

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And kept severely from resort of men,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That no man hath access by day to her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That no man hath recourse to her by night.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What lets but one may enter at her window?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And built so shelving that one cannot climb it

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Without apparent hazard of his life.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So bold Leander would adventure it.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This very night; for Love is like a child,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That longs for every thing that he can come by.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But, hark thee; I will go to her alone:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Under a cloak that is of any length.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, my good lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Then let me see thy cloak:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I'll get me one of such another length.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And here an engine fit for my proceeding.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Reads

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And slaves they are to me that send them flying:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: O, could their master come and go as lightly,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: While I, their king, that hither them importune,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Because myself do want my servants' fortune:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I curse myself, for they are sent by me,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That they should harbour where their lord would be.'

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What's here?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Why, Phaeton,--for thou art Merops' son,--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And with thy daring folly burn the world?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Go, base intruder! overweening slave!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And think my patience, more than thy desert,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Is privilege for thy departure hence:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thank me for this more than for all the favours

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But if thou linger in my territories

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Longer than swiftest expedition

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Will give thee time to leave our royal court,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I ever bore my daughter or thyself.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And why not death rather than living torment?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To die is to be banish'd from myself;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is self from self: a deadly banishment!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Unless it be to think that she is by

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And feed upon the shadow of perfection

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Except I be by Silvia in the night,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: There is no music in the nightingale;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Unless I look on Silvia in the day,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: There is no day for me to look upon;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: She is my essence, and I leave to be,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If I be not by her fair influence

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Tarry I here, I but attend on death:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS and LAUNCE

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Soho, soho!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What seest thou?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: but 'tis a Valentine.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Valentine?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Who then? his spirit?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Neither.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What then?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Nothing.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Who wouldst thou strike?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Nothing.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Villain, forbear.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is Silvia dead?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Hath she forsworn me?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What is your news?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That thou art banished--O, that's the news!--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O, I have fed upon this woe already,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And now excess of it will make me surfeit.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With them, upon her knees, her humble self;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As if but now they waxed pale for woe:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Besides, her intercession chafed him so,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When she for thy repeal was suppliant,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That to close prison he commanded her,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With many bitter threats of biding there.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Have some malignant power upon my life:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And study help for that which thou lament'st.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And manage it against despairing thoughts.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The time now serves not to expostulate:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And, ere I part with thee, confer at large

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Regard thy danger, and along with me!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Exeunt VALENTINE and PROTEUS

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel;

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: which is much in a bare Christian.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Pulling out a paper

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Here is the cate-log of her condition.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: carry; therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item:

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: with clean hands.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter SPEED

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: How now, Signior Launce! what news with your

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: mastership?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. What

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: news, then, in your paper?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, man, how black?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, as black as ink.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Let me read them.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst not read.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Thou liest; I can.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [Reads]  'Imprimis: She can milk.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Ay, that she can.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: heart, you brew good ale.'

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can sew.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That's as much as to say, Can she so?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can knit.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: she can knit him a stock?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: A special virtue: for then she need not be washed

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: and scoured.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can spin.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: spin for her living.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Here follow her vices.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Close at the heels of her virtues.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: of her breath.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That makes amends for her sour breath.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is proud.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannot

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: be ta'en from her.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is curst.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: will; for good things should be praised.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: than hairs, and more wealth than faults.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: mine, twice or thrice in that last article.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Rehearse that once more.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'--

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: is more than the wit, for the greater hides the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: less. What's next?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'And more faults than hairs,'--

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'And more wealth than faults.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: impossible,--

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: What then?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, then will I tell thee--that thy master stays

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: for thee at the North-gate.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: For me?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: better man than thee.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And must I go to him?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: that going will scarce serve the turn.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter DUKE and THURIO

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Since his exile she hath despised me most,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: That I am desperate of obtaining her.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This weak impress of love is as a figure

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A little time will melt her frozen thoughts

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: According to our proclamation gone?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Gone, my good lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: My daughter takes his going grievously.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Makes me the better to confer with thee.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Let me not live to look upon your grace.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I do, my lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How she opposes her against my will

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What might we do to make the girl forget

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The best way is to slander Valentine

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Three things that women highly hold in hate.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, if his enemy deliver it:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Then you must undertake to slander him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: 'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Especially against his very friend.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Where your good word cannot advantage him,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Your slander never can endamage him;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Therefore the office is indifferent,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Being entreated to it by your friend.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She shall not long continue love to him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But say this weed her love from Valentine,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Lest it should ravel and be good to none,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: You must provide to bottom it on me;

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Which must be done by praising me as much

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Because we know, on Valentine's report,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: You are already Love's firm votary

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon this warrant shall you have access

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Where you with Silvia may confer at large;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Where you may temper her by your persuasion

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As much as I can do, I will effect:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You must lay lime to tangle her desires

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Say that upon the altar of her beauty

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Moist it again, and frame some feeling line

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That may discover such integrity:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Make tigers tame and huge leviathans

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: After your dire-lamenting elegies,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Visit by night your lady's chamber-window

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With some sweet concert; to their instruments

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Let us into the city presently

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I have a sonnet that will serve the turn

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: To give the onset to thy good advice.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: About it, gentlemen!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And afterward determine our proceedings.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: SCENE I. The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Enter certain Outlaws

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE and SPEED

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye:

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Sir, we are undone; these are the villains

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: That all the travellers do fear so much.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My friends,--

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Peace! we'll hear him.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Then know that I have little wealth to lose:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: A man I am cross'd with adversity;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My riches are these poor habiliments,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Of which if you should here disfurnish me,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: You take the sum and substance that I have.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Whither travel you?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To Verona.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Whence came you?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: From Milan.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Have you long sojourned there?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: What, were you banish'd thence?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I was.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: For what offence?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For that which now torments me to rehearse:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Bu t yet I slew him manfully in fight,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Without false vantage or base treachery.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: But were you banish'd for so small a fault?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Have you the tongues?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My youthful travel therein made me happy,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Or else I often had been miserable.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Master, be one of them; it's an honourable kind of thievery.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Peace, villain!

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Nothing but my fortune.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Thrust from the company of awful men:

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Myself was from Verona banished

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: For practising to steal away a lady,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: An heir, and near allied unto the duke.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: And I for such like petty crimes as these,

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: But to the purpose--for we cite our faults,

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives;

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: And partly, seeing you are beautified

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: With goodly shape and by your own report

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: A linguist and a man of such perfection

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: As we do in our quality much want--

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Are you content to be our general?

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: To make a virtue of necessity

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Say ay, and be the captain of us all:

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Love thee as our commander and our king.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I take your offer and will live with you,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Provided that you do no outrages

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: On silly women or poor passengers.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: No, we detest such vile base practises.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: And show thee all the treasure we have got,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: SCENE II. Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Already have I been false to Valentine

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Under the colour of commending him,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I have access my own love to prefer:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When I protest true loyalty to her,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When to her beauty I commend my vows,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She bids me think how I have been forsworn

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The more it grows and fawneth on her still.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And give some evening music to her ear.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter THURIO and Musicians

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, gentle Thurio: for you know that love

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Will creep in service where it cannot go.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Who? Silvia?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, Silvia; for your sake.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes

speaker: Host
text_entry: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: I

speaker: Host
text_entry: pray you, why is it?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you where

speaker: Host
text_entry: you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But shall I hear him speak?

speaker: Host
text_entry: Ay, that you shall.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That will be music.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Music plays

speaker: Host
text_entry: Hark, hark!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Is he among these?

speaker: Host
text_entry: Ay: but, peace! let's hear 'em.

speaker: Host
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Who is Silvia? what is she,

speaker: Host
text_entry: That all our swains commend her?

speaker: Host
text_entry: Holy, fair and wise is she;

speaker: Host
text_entry: The heaven such grace did lend her,

speaker: Host
text_entry: That she might admired be.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Is she kind as she is fair?

speaker: Host
text_entry: For beauty lives with kindness.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Love doth to her eyes repair,

speaker: Host
text_entry: To help him of his blindness,

speaker: Host
text_entry: And, being help'd, inhabits there.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Then to Silvia let us sing,

speaker: Host
text_entry: That Silvia is excelling;

speaker: Host
text_entry: She excels each mortal thing

speaker: Host
text_entry: Upon the dull earth dwelling:

speaker: Host
text_entry: To her let us garlands bring.

speaker: Host
text_entry: How now! are you sadder than you were before? How

speaker: Host
text_entry: do you, man? the music likes you not.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: You mistake; the musician likes me not.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Why, my pretty youth?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: He plays false, father.

speaker: Host
text_entry: How? out of tune on the strings?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: heart-strings.

speaker: Host
text_entry: You have a quick ear.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Ay, I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow heart.

speaker: Host
text_entry: I perceive you delight not in music.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Not a whit, when it jars so.

speaker: Host
text_entry: Hark, what fine change is in the music!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Ay, that change is the spite.

speaker: Host
text_entry: You would have them always play but one thing?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I would always have one play but one thing.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk on

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Often resort unto this gentlewoman?

speaker: Host
text_entry: I tell you what Launce, his man, told me: he loved

speaker: Host
text_entry: her out of all nick.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Where is Launce?

speaker: Host
text_entry: Gone to seek his dog; which tomorrow, by his

speaker: Host
text_entry: master's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Peace! stand aside: the company parts.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sir Thurio, fear not you: I will so plead

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That you shall say my cunning drift excels.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Where meet we?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: At Saint Gregory's well.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Exeunt THURIO and Musicians

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Enter SILVIA above

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Madam, good even to your ladyship.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I thank you for your music, gentlemen.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Who is that that spake?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Sir Proteus, as I take it.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: What's your will?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That I may compass yours.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: You have your wish; my will is even this:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: That presently you hie you home to bed.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: To be seduced by thy flattery,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: That hast deceived so many with thy vows?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Return, return, and make thy love amends.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I am so far from granting thy request

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And by and by intend to chide myself

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But she is dead.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]        'Twere false, if I should speak it;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: For I am sure she is not buried.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Survives; to whom, thyself art witness,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I am betroth'd: and art thou not ashamed

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: To wrong him with thy importunacy?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And so suppose am I; for in his grave

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Assure thyself my love is buried.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  He heard not that.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The picture that is hanging in your chamber;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For since the substance of your perfect self

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Is else devoted, I am but a shadow;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And to your shadow will I make true love.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  If 'twere a substance, you would, sure,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: deceive it,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And make it but a shadow, as I am.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I am very loath to be your idol, sir;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: But since your falsehood shall become you well

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: To worship shadows and adore false shapes,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Send to me in the morning and I'll send it:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And so, good rest.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As wretches have o'ernight

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That wait for execution in the morn.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exeunt PROTEUS and SILVIA severally

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Host, will you go?

speaker: Host
text_entry: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?

speaker: Host
text_entry: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost

speaker: Host
text_entry: day.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Not so; but it hath been the longest night

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That e'er I watch'd and the most heaviest.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: SCENE III. The same.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter EGLAMOUR

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: This is the hour that Madam Silvia

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Entreated me to call and know her mind:

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: There's some great matter she'ld employ me in.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Madam, madam!

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Enter SILVIA above

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Who calls?

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Your servant and your friend;

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: One that attends your ladyship's command.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: As many, worthy lady, to yourself:

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: According to your ladyship's impose,

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: I am thus early come to know what service

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: It is your pleasure to command me in.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman--

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not--

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplish'd:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Thou art not ignorant what dear good will

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I bear unto the banish'd Valentine,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Nor how my father would enforce me marry

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhors.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: No grief did ever come so near thy heart

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: As when thy lady and thy true love died,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Upon whose grave thou vow'dst pure chastity.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I do desire thy worthy company,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Upon whose faith and honour I repose.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And on the justice of my flying hence,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: To keep me from a most unholy match,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I do desire thee, even from a heart

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: To bear me company and go with me:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: If not, to hide what I have said to thee,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: That I may venture to depart alone.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Madam, I pity much your grievances;

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Which since I know they virtuously are placed,

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: I give consent to go along with you,

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Recking as little what betideth me

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: As much I wish all good befortune you.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: When will you go?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: This evening coming.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Where shall I meet you?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: At Friar Patrick's cell,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Where I intend holy confession.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Exeunt severally

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Enter LAUNCE, with his his Dog

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: puppy; one that I saved from drowning, when three or

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I have taught him, even as one would say precisely,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'thus I would teach a dog.' I was sent to deliver

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master;

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg:

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: O, 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: in all companies! I would have, as one should say,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I think verily he had been hanged for't; sure as I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: live, he had suffered for't; you shall judge. He

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: thrusts me himself into the company of three or four

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: gentlemanlike dogs under the duke's table: he had

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: not been there--bless the mark!--a pissing while, but

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: all the chamber smelt him. 'Out with the dog!' says

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: one: 'What cur is that?' says another: 'Whip him

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: out' says the third: 'Hang him up' says the duke.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I, having been acquainted with the smell before,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: whips the dogs: 'Friend,' quoth I, 'you mean to whip

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: the dog?' 'Ay, marry, do I,' quoth he. 'You do him

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: the more wrong,' quoth I; ''twas I did the thing you

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wot of.' He makes me no more ado, but whips me out

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: of the chamber. How many masters would do this for

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have sat in the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: stocks for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: been executed; I have stood on the pillory for geese

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Thou thinkest not of this now. Nay, I remember the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Silvia: did not I bid thee still mark me and do as I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: do? when didst thou see me heave up my leg and make

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? didst

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: thou ever see me do such a trick?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS and JULIA

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And will employ thee in some service presently.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: In what you please: I'll do what I can.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I hope thou wilt.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To LAUNCE

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How now, you whoreson peasant!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Where have you been these two days loitering?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And what says she to my little jewel?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells you

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But she received my dog?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought him

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: back again.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Ay, sir: the other squirrel was stolen from me by

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: the hangman boys in the market-place: and then I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Or ne'er return again into my sight.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Away, I say! stay'st thou to vex me here?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit LAUNCE

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sebastian, I have entertained thee,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Partly that I have need of such a youth

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That can with some discretion do my business,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But chiefly for thy face and thy behavior,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which, if my augury deceive me not,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go presently and take this ring with thee,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Deliver it to Madam Silvia:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She loved me well deliver'd it to me.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: She is dead, belike?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Not so; I think she lives.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Alas!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I cannot choose

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But pity her.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Because methinks that she loved you as well

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As you do love your lady Silvia:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: She dreams of him that has forgot her love;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: You dote on her that cares not for your love.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: 'Tis pity love should be so contrary;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And thinking of it makes me cry 'alas!'

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Well, give her that ring and therewithal

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: How many women would do such a message?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Alas, poor Proteus! thou hast entertain'd

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Alas, poor fool! why do I pity him

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That with his very heart despiseth me?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Because he loves her, he despiseth me;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Because I love him I must pity him.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: This ring I gave him when he parted from me,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To bind him to remember my good will;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And now am I, unhappy messenger,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To plead for that which I would not obtain,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To carry that which I would have refused,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To praise his faith which I would have dispraised.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I am my master's true-confirmed love;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But cannot be true servant to my master,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Unless I prove false traitor to myself.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter SILVIA, attended

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my mean

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: What would you with her, if that I be she?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If you be she, I do entreat your patience

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: From whom?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: O, he sends you for a picture.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Ay, madam.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Ursula, bring my picture here.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Go give your master this: tell him from me,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Madam, please you peruse this letter.--

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Pardon me, madam; I have unadvised

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Deliver'd you a paper that I should not:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: This is the letter to your ladyship.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: There, hold!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I will not look upon your master's lines:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I know they are stuff'd with protestations

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And full of new-found oaths; which he will break

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: As easily as I do tear his paper.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: The more shame for him that he sends it me;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: For I have heard him say a thousand times

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: His Julia gave it him at his departure.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Though his false finger have profaned the ring,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: She thanks you.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: What say'st thou?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Dost thou know her?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Almost as well as I do know myself:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To think upon her woes I do protest

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That I have wept a hundred several times.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Is she not passing fair?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: When she did think my master loved her well,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: She, in my judgment, was as fair as you:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But since she did neglect her looking-glass

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And threw her sun-expelling mask away,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And pinch'd the lily-tincture of her face,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That now she is become as black as I.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: How tall was she?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: About my stature; for at Pentecost,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: When all our pageants of delight were play'd,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Our youth got me to play the woman's part,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And I was trimm'd in Madam Julia's gown,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Which served me as fit, by all men's judgments,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: As if the garment had been made for me:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Therefore I know she is about my height.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And at that time I made her weep agood,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: For I did play a lamentable part:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Which I so lively acted with my tears

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I weep myself to think upon thy words.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Exit SILVIA, with attendants

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I hope my master's suit will be but cold,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Since she respects my mistress' love so much.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Alas, how love can trifle with itself!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Here is her picture: let me see; I think,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If I had such a tire, this face of mine

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Were full as lovely as is this of hers:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And yet the painter flatter'd her a little,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Unless I flatter with myself too much.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If that be all the difference in his love,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I'll get me such a colour'd periwig.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: What should it be that he respects in her

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: But I can make respective in myself,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: If this fond Love were not a blinded god?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Come, shadow, come and take this shadow up,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Thou shalt be worshipp'd, kiss'd, loved and adored!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And, were there sense in his idolatry,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: My substance should be statue in thy stead.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: I should have scratch'd out your unseeing eyes

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: To make my master out of love with thee!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: SCENE I. Milan. An abbey.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter EGLAMOUR

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: The sun begins to gild the western sky;

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: And now it is about the very hour

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: She will not fail, for lovers break not hours,

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Unless it be to come before their time;

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: So much they spur their expedition.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: See where she comes.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Enter SILVIA

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Lady, a happy evening!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Out at the postern by the abbey-wall:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I fear I am attended by some spies.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: If we recover that, we are sure enough.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: EGLAMOUR
text_entry: Enter THURIO, PROTEUS, and JULIA

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, sir, I find her milder than she was;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: What, that my leg is too long?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No; that it is too little.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  But love will not be spurr'd to what

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: it loathes.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: What says she to my face?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She says it is a fair one.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  'Tis true; such pearls as put out

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: ladies' eyes;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: For I had rather wink than look on them.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: How likes she my discourse?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ill, when you talk of war.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: What says she to my valour?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: What says she to my birth?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That you are well derived.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  True; from a gentleman to a fool.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Considers she my possessions?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, ay; and pities them.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Wherefore?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  That such an ass should owe them.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That they are out by lease.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Here comes the duke.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter DUKE

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Not I.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Saw you my daughter?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Neither.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Why then,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And Eglamour is in her company.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: As he in penance wander'd through the forest;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Him he knew well, and guess'd that it was she,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But, being mask'd, he was not sure of it;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Besides, she did intend confession

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But mount you presently and meet with me

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon the rising of the mountain-foot

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That leads towards Mantua, whither they are fled:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: That flies her fortune when it follows her.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And I will follow, more to cross that love

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: SCENE III. The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter Outlaws with SILVIA

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Come, come,

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: A thousand more mischances than this one

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Have learn'd me how to brook this patiently.

speaker: Second Outlaw
text_entry: Come, bring her away.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: But Moyses and Valerius follow him.

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;

speaker: Third Outlaw
text_entry: The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,

speaker: First Outlaw
text_entry: And will not use a woman lawlessly.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: How use doth breed a habit in a man!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I better brook than flourishing peopled towns:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And to the nightingale's complaining notes

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Tune my distresses and record my woes.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Leave not the mansion so long tenantless,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And leave no memory of what it was!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Repair me with thy presence, Silvia;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What halloing and what stir is this to-day?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: These are my mates, that make their wills their law,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Have some unhappy passenger in chase.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: They love me well; yet I have much to do

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To keep them from uncivil outrages.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Withdraw thee, Valentine: who's this comes here?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS, SILVIA, and JULIA

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Madam, this service I have done for you,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Though you respect not aught your servant doth,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To hazard life and rescue you from him

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That would have forced your honour and your love;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A smaller boon than this I cannot beg

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: [Aside]  How like a dream is this I see and hear!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But by my coming I have made you happy.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: [Aside]  And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I would have been a breakfast to the beast,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And full as much, for more there cannot be,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: I do detest false perjured Proteus.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Would I not undergo for one calm look!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When women cannot love where they're beloved!

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Descended into perjury, to love me.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: And that's far worse than none; better have none

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Than plural faith which is too much by one:

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: In love

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Who respects friend?

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: All men but Proteus.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Can no way change you to a milder form,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And love you 'gainst the nature of love,--force ye.

speaker: SILVIA
text_entry: O heaven!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Thou friend of an ill fashion!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Valentine!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For such is a friend now; treacherous man!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Who should be trusted, when one's own right hand

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I am sorry I must never trust thee more,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But count the world a stranger for thy sake.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: 'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My shame and guilt confounds me.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Forgive me, Valentine: if hearty sorrow

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Be a sufficient ransom for offence,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I tender 't here; I do as truly suffer

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As e'er I did commit.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Then I am paid;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And once again I do receive thee honest.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Who by repentance is not satisfied

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And, that my love may appear plain and free,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: O me unhappy!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Swoons

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Look to the boy.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, boy! why, wag! how now! what's the matter?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Look up; speak.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: to Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was never done.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Where is that ring, boy?

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Here 'tis; this is it.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How! let me see:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But how camest thou by this ring? At my depart

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I gave this unto Julia.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And Julia herself did give it me;

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How! Julia!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And entertain'd 'em deeply in her heart.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Such an immodest raiment, if shame live

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: In a disguise of love:

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Than men their minds! 'tis true.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: O heaven! were man

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But constant, he were perfect. That one error

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Come, come, a hand from either:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Let me be blest to make this happy close;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: 'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: And I mine.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO

speaker: Outlaws
text_entry: A prize, a prize, a prize!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Forbear, forbear, I say! it is my lord the duke.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Banished Valentine.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Valentine!

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Come not within the measure of my wrath;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Verona shall not hold thee. Here she stands;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Take but possession of her with a touch:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I;

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I hold him but a fool that will endanger

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: His body for a girl that loves him not:

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The more degenerate and base art thou,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To make such means for her as thou hast done

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And leave her on such slight conditions.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now, by the honour of my ancestry,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And think thee worthy of an empress' love:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Know then, I here forget all former griefs,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Plead a new state in thy unrivall'd merit,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thou art a gentleman and well derived;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To grant one boom that I shall ask of you.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I grant it, for thine own, whate'er it be.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: These banish'd men that I have kept withal

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Are men endued with worthy qualities:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Forgive them what they have committed here

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And let them be recall'd from their exile:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: They are reformed, civil, full of good

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Come, let us go: we will include all jars

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And, as we walk along, I dare be bold

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: With our discourse to make your grace to smile.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What think you of this page, my lord?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What mean you by that saying?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That you will wonder what hath fortuned.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The story of your loves discovered:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That done, our day of marriage shall be yours;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Exeunt
